Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Powerful and Tunable Electron Donors for Reduction Chemistry and Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Dennis L. Lichtenberger and Jon T. Njardarson of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Arizona and Professor Dennis H. Evans of the Department of Chemistry at Purdue University are developing the chemistry of molecules with the ability to donate electrons in non-polar solvents. Such strong electron donor molecules may unlock many new chemical transformations and catalytic processes. The development of more powerful and tunable electron donors has broad impacts on wide areas of chemistry and society, from additions to the toolbox of synthetic organic chemistry and natural products chemistry to insights into the catalytic production of clean and sustainable fuels, which is one of the grand challenges facing science today. The project combines the complementary expertise of Professor Njardarson (organic synthesis), Professor Lichtenberger (inorganic chemistry, spectroscopy, thermodynamics and mechanisms) and Professor Evans (electrochemistry), and benefits from collaborations with other synthetic and theoretical chemists. The project also has broad community participation. Teachers at schools with large Native American student populations participate in the research.

The research uses gas phase photoelectron spectroscopy to study dimetal complexes with bicyclic guanidinate ligands that are the strongest electron donors yet known. This project investigates the structure, dynamics and mechanisms of this class of electron donors using a range of synthetic, spectroscopic, electrochemical, and computational techniques. Specific aims of the project are to: (1) investigate electron transfer reactions in organic chemistry that are difficult or impossible with current electron donors, such as the hydrodehalogenation of aryl chlorides to detoxify polychlorinated byphenyls and other organic halides in the environment, and (2) characterize electrocatalytic processes such as the reduction of protons to hydrogen by strong donors. Chemical modifications within this class of molecules are being pursued to produce a range of electron donor abilities for selective chemical transformations of commercial interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Molecules that serve as electron donors are the basis for a large part of chemical reactivity and catalysis, biological functions, energy science, and device performances (such as solar cells and display screens) that involve movement of electrons. In this project the preparation and properties of a special class of dimetal molecules (shown in the Figure) that are classified as "super-electron-donor" molecules have been investigated. The two metal atoms in the core of these molecules are connected by a strong quadruple bond, and this dimetal core is surrounded by insulating organic molecules called bicyclic guanidinates. The arrangement of the four guanidinates around the dimetal core gives a structure similar to a paddlewheel, which has become the common name of this general class of molecules.  Taken separately the dimetal core and the guanidinates have interesting properties, but when put together as in the Figure they cooperate to produce the strongest uncharged electron donor species yet discovered. Interestingly, these species are very stable thermally; they have been heated to over 350 °C (over 650 °F) without breaking down, and samples have been shipped and stored for many years at room temperature without signs of decomposition. In contrast, when the molecules are utilized for their electron donor ability they are extremely reactive (described as being extremely "hot" for chemical reactivity), and must be handled in atmospheres that are devoid of oxygen and that are completely dry. These properties open new vistas for chemical synthesis and catalysis. The project has found that single-electron transfer reactions in organic chemistry that are difficult or impossible even at high temperature with current donors, such as dehalogenation reactions, are fast at room temperature with these dimetal super-electron-donors. These dimetal super-electron-donors are also found to be the only naturally uncharged molecules able to produce molecular hydrogen from weak proton sources. Another attractive feature of these systems is that they are tunable for specific chemical reactions. Computational modeling in this project has predicted that slight chemical modifications to these molecules will yield even stronger super-electron-donors.

The discoveries in this project have broad impacts on science and society. For one, these dimetal guanidinate species add to the toolbox of chemistry with new chemical capabilities for important processes. For instance, the dehalogenation reactions are relevant to the search for sustainable and safe methods to detoxify polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and other organic halides that poison the environment. The production of molecular hydrogen is relevant to the search for sustainable methods to produce energy-dense fuels without the production of green-house gases. In addition to the intellectual merits, the project has made broad contributions to developing the next generation of scientists through outreach to K-12 students, promoting diversity, and training of undergraduate and graduate students. Participants in this project have served as coaches in Title 1 elementary schools to help develop science curricula and demonstrations for underprivileged students, and have been leaders in the Program to Advance Women Scientists (PAWS) and in the Women in STEM Student Council (WiSSC) to attract women to the STEM fields. The project supported the website for "Chemistry by Design" and associated apps (iphones, ipads, android devices) that provide an interactive virtual flashcard for students to test their skills using known synthetic sequences (http://chemistrybydesign.oia.arizona.edu) and the popular website of pharmaceutical posters (http://njardarson.lab.arizona.edu/content/top-pharmaceuticals-poster).

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2020
Modified by: Dennis L Lichtenberger

Image
  • Left: Chemical drawing of the super-electron-donor molecules, composed of a dimetal core surrounded by organic groups. Right: Surface of the molecule; the red color highlights the region of high electron donor potential resulting from interaction of the dimetal core with the surrounding groups.
    Dennis L. Lichtenberger
    Copyrighted
    Dennis L Lichtenberger
    Structure of Dimetal Super-Electron-Donors
